noun.description: The action of drawing or pulling something over a surface, especially a road or track.
examples: a primitive vehicle used in animal traction

noun.description: The grip of a tire on a road or a wheel on a rail.
examples: his car hit a patch of ice and lost traction

noun.description: The extent to which a product, idea, etc., gains popularity or acceptance.
examples: analysts predicted that the technology would rapidly gain traction in the corporate market
if a film got a little traction, a wider release could be negotiated

noun.description: The application of a sustained pull on a limb or muscle, especially in order to maintain the position of a fractured bone or to correct a deformity.

origin: Late Middle English (denoting contraction, such as that of a muscle): from French, or from medieval Latin tractio(n-), from Latin trahere draw, pull. Current senses date from the early 19th century.
